criteria: Ability to accurately identify and describe the roles of parents, guardians, and trusted adults as sources of information and guidance regarding medicines.
Understanding the types of information parents/guardians/trusted adults can provide about medicines (e.g., dosage, side effects, interactions).
Recognizing the importance of seeking guidance from parents, guardians, and trusted adults regarding medicine use and safety.
descriptions: The student cannot identify any appropriate adults or provides inaccurate information about their roles.
The student identifies one appropriate adult but struggles to explain their role in providing medicine-related guidance.
The student identifies at least two appropriate adults and provides a basic description of their roles.
The student identifies multiple appropriate adults and accurately explains their roles in providing information and guidance about medicines.
The student comprehensively identifies appropriate adults, accurately explains their roles, and provides examples of situations where these individuals can offer support.

The student demonstrates exceptional understanding by not only identifying and explaining the roles of appropriate adults but also recognizing the importance of seeking guidance from them and understanding their limitations.
The student shows no understanding of the types of information parents, guardians, or trusted adults can provide.
The student demonstrates a vague understanding of one type of information these adults can provide.
The student identifies at least two types of information these adults can provide.
The student accurately explains multiple types of information these adults can provide, such as dosage, side effects, and interactions.
The student comprehensively explains the types of information and emphasizes the importance of accurate and reliable information.
The student provides an insightful explanation of the nuances of information, potentially mentioning the need to verify information and the consequences of misinformation.
The student does not recognize the importance of seeking guidance from appropriate adults.
The student acknowledges the importance of seeking guidance but struggles to explain why.
The student provides a basic explanation of why it's important to seek guidance from appropriate adults.
The student clearly explains the importance of seeking guidance, emphasizing safety and accuracy.
The student demonstrates a deep understanding of the importance of seeking guidance and relates it to personal health and well-being.
The student articulates the importance of seeking guidance and demonstrates an ability to advocate for seeking advice from trusted adults, promoting responsible medicine use.
